para.text: When making a determination that a building is vacant, the Mayor shall consider the following:
Neighbor complaints;
Advisory Neighborhood Commission certification;
Accumulated mail, fliers, or newspapers;
Past due utility notices, disconnected utilities, or low utility usage inconsistent with regular and habitual occupancy;
Presence of overgrown vegetation, dead or diseased trees, or noxious weeds;
Absence of furnishings or personal items consistent with habitation;
Building is open to casual entry or trespass; and
Any other criteria the Mayor deems relevant.
When making a determination that a vacant building is a blighted vacant building, the Mayor shall consider the following:
Incidence of illegal activity, as documented by police reports;
Whether the vacant building is the subject of a condemnation proceeding before the Board for the Condemnation of Insanitary Buildings;
Referrals to the Department of Buildings from other District agencies;
One or more windows, doors, or other means of entry are missing or boarded up;
Collapsing, missing, or deteriorating walls, roof, stairs, porches, balconies, chimneys, and other building elements;
Siding or exterior walls that are seriously damaged, missing, or deteriorating;
Trash and debris are improperly stored or accumulated on the premises;
Building shows visible signs of vandalism, such as graffiti;
Presence of mold, algae, abandoned or wild animals, or insect or pest infestation; and
Any other criteria the Mayor deems relevant.
